elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of (L)-N-(2-cyano-benzyl)-(S)-proline with NaN3 and Zn(ClO4)2 as a Lewis acid catalyst and H2O as a solvent gave {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(HClO4)](0.25HClO4)} n (1) (TBPR = (S)-N-2-tetrazoylbenzylproline), an unique homochiral one-dimensional cage- or tanklike metal−organic framework (MOF) in which the cage or tank is filled with free perchloric acid. Permittivity property measurements reveal that 1 exhibits a high dielectric loss, which suggests it could be a potentially useful material for dielectric heating (such as electrocaloric effect), while ferroelectric property measurements show a possible hysteresis loop with a large remnant polarization (P r = 1.8 μC/cm2) and a lower closing mouth route.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reaction of (L)-N-(2-cyano-benzyl)-(S)-proline with NaN3 and Zn(ClO4)2 as a Lewis acid catalyst and H2O as a solvent gave {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(HClO4)](0.25HClO4)} n  (1) (TBPR = (S)-N-2-tetrazoylbenzylproline), an unique homochiral one-dimensional cage- or tanklike metal-organic framework (MOF) in which the cage or tank is filled with free perchloric acid. Permittivity property measurements reveal that 1 exhibits a high dielectric loss, which suggests it could be a potentially useful material for dielectric heating (such as electrocaloric effect), while ferroelectric property measurements show a possible hysteresis loop with a large remnant polarization (P r = 1.8 μC/cm2) and a lower closing mouth route.

Permittivity and ferroelectric property measurements reveal that 1 not only exhibits a high dielectric loss but also displays a possible hysteresis loop with a large remnant polarization (P r = 1.8 μC/cm2) and a lower closing mouth route.

Permittivity and ferroelectric property measurements reveal that 1 not only exhibits a high dielectric loss but also displays a possible hysteresis loop with a large remnant polarization (P r = 1.8 μC/cm2) and a lower closing mouth route.

elements.content: Ceramic materials such as Ba2Ti9O20 and Ba3ZnTa2O9 used in dielectric resonators and filters to store and transfer microwave communication signals are required to have a high dielectric constant (DC), low dielectric loss (DL) (low conversion of signal to heat), and temperature stable resonant frequency. On the other hand, materials that possess a high DC and high DL (high conversion of signal to heat) have been widely used in medical and semiconductor applications where heat is produced by induction heating (or dielectric heating techniques). In the literature, a number of pure inorganic compounds have been reported to display high DC and low DL, while several pure organic compounds and polymers have been demonstrated to exhibit relatively low DC and medium DL. In contrast, studies toward developing dielectric materials based on metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained sparse. This is surprising in view of recent work by us and others which showed that in situ (2 + 3) cycloaddition chiral ligand synthesis under hydrothermal conditions provided a convenient and simple route to novel MOFs. Potentially useful magnetic and nonlinear optic (NLO)/second harmonic generation (SHG) properties also were displayed by these materials. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and dielectric properties of {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(HClO4)](0.25HClO4)} n (1); TBPR = (S)-N-2-tetrazoylbenzylproline, a one-dimensional (1D) MOF pipelike cage containing channels filled with free perchloric acid molecules. 1 was obtained as colorless block crystals from the reaction of N-2-cyanobenzyl-(S)-proline (H-CBPR) with NaN3 and Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O as a Lewis acid catalyst under hydrothermal conditions (Scheme ). To our knowledge, the construction of MOF structures containing acid molecules is unprecedented.
elements.clean_text: Ceramic materials such as Ba2Ti9O20 and Ba3ZnTa2O9 used in dielectric resonators and filters to store and transfer microwave communication signals are required to have a high dielectric constant (DC), low dielectric loss (DL) (low conversion of signal to heat), and temperature stable resonant frequency. On the other hand, materials that possess a high DC and high DL (high conversion of signal to heat) have been widely used in medical and semiconductor applications where heat is produced by induction heating (or dielectric heating techniques). In the literature, a number of pure inorganic compounds have been reported to display high DC and low DL, while several pure organic compounds and polymers have been demonstrated to exhibit relatively low DC and medium DL. In contrast, studies toward developing dielectric materials based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained sparse. This is surprising in view of recent work by us and others which showed that in situ (2 + 3) cycloaddition chiral ligand synthesis under hydrothermal conditions provided a convenient and simple route to novel MOFs. Potentially useful magnetic and nonlinear optic (NLO)/second harmonic generation (SHG) properties also were displayed by these materials. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and dielectric properties of {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(HClO4)](0.25HClO4)} n  (1); TBPR = (S)-N-2-tetrazoylbenzylproline, a one-dimensional (1D) MOF pipelike cage containing channels filled with free perchloric acid molecules. 1 was obtained as colorless block crystals from the reaction of N-2-cyanobenzyl-(S)-proline (H-CBPR) with NaN3 and Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O as a Lewis acid catalyst under hydrothermal conditions (Scheme ). To our knowledge, the construction of MOF structures containing acid molecules is unprecedented.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gs1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2009-00100w_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

IR spectroscopic analysis of 1 revealed a strong peak at 1098 cm−1, a medium-broad peak at 1436 cm−1, and a strong sharp peak at 1621 cm−1 that could be assigned to the presence of perchlorate anions, newly formed tetrazoyl functionality, and ν(CO) stretch, respectively. A medium-broad peak at 3451 cm−1 suggests that the perchlorate anion is most likely present in the protonated form as HClO4. The presence of perchloric acid in 1 was confirmed by dissolving a sample in water and allowing it to stand for 2 weeks and obtaining the resulting solution with a pH value of ca. 4.5. Also, to further confirm this aspect, we have completed the crystal structure determination of {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(DClO4)](0.25DClO4)} n (2) and its IR measurement (see ).
elements.clean_text: IR spectroscopic analysis of 1 revealed a strong peak at 1098 cm-1, a medium-broad peak at 1436 cm-1, and a strong sharp peak at 1621 cm-1 that could be assigned to the presence of perchlorate anions, newly formed tetrazoyl functionality, and ν(CO) stretch, respectively. A medium-broad peak at 3451 cm-1 suggests that the perchlorate anion is most likely present in the protonated form as HClO4. The presence of perchloric acid in 1 was confirmed by dissolving a sample in water and allowing it to stand for 2 weeks and obtaining the resulting solution with a pH value of ca. 4.5. Also, to further confirm this aspect, we have completed the crystal structure determination of {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(DClO4)](0.25DClO4)} n  (2) and its IR measurement (see ).

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure determination of 1 reveals that the local coordination geometry around the Zn center can be best described as a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid composed of an equatorial plane formed by three N atoms from the proline ring and tetrazoyl group, and two O atoms from the two carboxylate groups that occupy the two respective apical positions (Figure ). Four Zn(TBPR) units are connected together through four tetrazoyl groups in a 1,3-μ-CN4 manner which leads to the formation of a cage- or pipelike four-membered ring system comprised of Zn4(CN4)4 with a perchloric acid molecule sitting inside the cage. Interestingly, one tetrazoyl nitrogen atom N(3) is hydrogen bonded to the oxygen atom O(5) of this perchloric acid with a distance of 3.19(4) Å which potentially stabilizes the structure. Each cage- or pipelike structure has a rim diameter of 5.613 Å and a wall comprised of bridging carboxylate and phenyl groups. Notably, four of these pipelike structures are also connected together through supramolecular H-bonding facilitated by a perchloric acid molecule that sits outside these structures; in this arrangement, HClO4 occupies a 4-fold rotational symmetry position. The average Cl−O bond lengths of HClO4 (1.382(10) and 1.397(9)Å) are shorter than an average distance of 1.43 Å for the counter perchlorate ion ClO4 − but in the normal range for free ClO4 − anion in other M∥ complexes (1.38−1.40 Å). The C1(1)−O(3) and C1(2)−O(5) bond lengths of 1.347(4) and 1.363(5) Å are comparable to those found in [Cu4Ldur(μ2-OMe)4](ClO4)·HClO4·2/3MeOH(Ldur = 1,2,4,5-tetrakis-(1,4,7-triazacyclonon-1-ylmethyl) benzene). A chelating five-membered ring is found along the N−C−C−O−Zn bonding sequence. The second O atom of the carboxylate group acts as a bridge to another Zn center. The TBPR ligand thus acts as pentadentate linker that connects four Zn centers together to give a unique homochiral 1D cage- or pipelike chain (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystal structure determination of 1 reveals that the local coordination geometry around the Zn center can be best described as a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid composed of an equatorial plane formed by three N atoms from the proline ring and tetrazoyl group, and two O atoms from the two carboxylate groups that occupy the two respective apical positions (Figure ). Four Zn(TBPR) units are connected together through four tetrazoyl groups in a 1,3-μ-CN4 manner which leads to the formation of a cage- or pipelike four-membered ring system comprised of Zn4(CN4)4 with a perchloric acid molecule sitting inside the cage. Interestingly, one tetrazoyl nitrogen atom N(3) is hydrogen bonded to the oxygen atom O(5) of this perchloric acid with a distance of 3.19(4) Å which potentially stabilizes the structure. Each cage- or pipelike structure has a rim diameter of 5.613 Å and a wall comprised of bridging carboxylate and phenyl groups. Notably, four of these pipelike structures are also connected together through supramolecular H-bonding facilitated by a perchloric acid molecule that sits outside these structures; in this arrangement, HClO4 occupies a 4-fold rotational symmetry position. The average Cl-O bond lengths of HClO4 (1.382(10) and 1.397(9)Å) are shorter than an average distance of 1.43 Å for the counter perchlorate ion ClO4 - but in the normal range for free ClO4 - anion in other M∥ complexes (1.38-1.40 Å). The C1(1)-O(3) and C1(2)-O(5) bond lengths of 1.347(4) and 1.363(5) Å are comparable to those found in [Cu4Ldur(μ2-OMe)4](ClO4)⋅HClO4⋅2/3MeOH(Ldur = 1,2,4,5-tetrakis-(1,4,7-triazacyclonon-1-ylmethyl) benzene). A chelating five-membered ring is found along the N-C-C-O-Zn bonding sequence. The second O atom of the carboxylate group acts as a bridge to another Zn center. The TBPR ligand thus acts as pentadentate linker that connects four Zn centers together to give a unique homochiral 1D cage- or pipelike chain (Figure ).

elements.content: Asymmetric unit representation of 1 in which two position free perchloric acid molecules are clearly seen in the unit where the local coordination geometry around Zn is highlighted in the right corner. Typical bond distances (Å): Zn−N 1.993(2), 2.000(2), 2.111(2); Zn−O 2.007(3), 2.023(2); Cl−O 1.323(12), 1.347(14), 1.397(14), 1.459(10).

elements.content: (a) Side and top views of the four-membered-ring comprised of Zn4(CN4) filled with a free perchloric acid molecule (yellow column) in 1 with carboxylate bridging mode extending the four-membered ring to form a pipe. (b) Free perchoric acid (yellow column) sitting in a 4-fold rotation position connecting together four pipes of 1 through supramolecular H-bonding.

(b) Free perchoric acid (yellow column) sitting in a 4-fold rotation position connecting together four pipes of 1 through supramolecular H-bonding.

elements.content: Figure shows the temperature dependence of the dielectric constant ε1(T) of a pellet specimen of 1 coated with conducting Ag-glue, between a frequency range of 1 kHz to 1 MHz. ε1(T) reaches a value of above 80 at low frequency and 250 K, and the frequency dielectric constant is strongly temperature dependent over the measured temperature range. In contrast, an increase in temperature reveals that there is a second ε1(T) (static dielectric constant (ε0) ca. 71, see ) that reaches a maximum peak value of ca. 2700 at 360 K and drops approximately 3-fold as the temperature increases where the temperature is above 400 K; the dielectric constant [from 620 to 410] is weakly affected with frequency decrease ranging from 0.1 kHz to 0.316 kHz (Figure b). It is worth noting that this differs from that of CaCu3Ti4O12, which has been reported to exhibit a sharp 103-fold drop, presumably due to well-known ferroelectrics.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the temperature dependence of the dielectric constant ε1(T) of a pellet specimen of 1 coated with conducting Ag-glue, between a frequency range of 1 kHz to 1 MHz. ε1(T) reaches a value of above 80 at low frequency and 250 K, and the frequency dielectric constant is strongly temperature dependent over the measured temperature range. In contrast, an increase in temperature reveals that there is a second ε1(T) (static dielectric constant (ε0) ca. 71, see ) that reaches a maximum peak value of ca. 2700 at 360 K and drops approximately 3-fold as the temperature increases where the temperature is above 400 K; the dielectric constant [from 620 to 410] is weakly affected with frequency decrease ranging from 0.1 kHz to 0.316 kHz (Figure b). It is worth noting that this differs from that of CaCu3Ti4O12, which has been reported to exhibit a sharp 103-fold drop, presumably due to well-known ferroelectrics.

elements.content: (a) The low temperature dependence of the dielectric constant of 1 at various frequencies between 1 kHz and 1 MHz. (b) The medium temperature dependence of the dielectric constant of 1 at various frequencies between 100 Hz and 1 MHz.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The low temperature dependence of the dielectric constant of 1 at various frequencies between 1 kHz and 1 MHz. (b) The medium temperature dependence of the dielectric constant of 1 at various frequencies between 100 Hz and 1 MHz.

elements.content: 1 was found to crystallize in polar point group (C 4) which is a characteristic feature of ferroelectric materials. The electric field-induced polarization of 1 was evaluated with a Radiant Technologies’ Precision II ferroelectric tester. As shown in Figure , a single crystal of 1 approximately along the (010) plane exhibited possible polarization hysteresis, which is a well-known characteristic of ferroelectric materials with a P r (remnant polarization) = 1.8 μC/cm2 and almost comparable to peptide-induced BaTiO3. Such a large P r with smaller coercive electric field (∼2.5 kV) is unprecedented in MOF and may be due to the presence of anion perchlorate in this channel, like a typical H-bonded ferroelectric TGS (triglycine sulfate). This respect was confirmed by its large dielectric constant.
elements.clean_text: 1 was found to crystallize in polar point group (C 4) which is a characteristic feature of ferroelectric materials. The electric field-induced polarization of 1 was evaluated with a Radiant Technologies' Precision II ferroelectric tester. As shown in Figure , a single crystal of 1 approximately along the (010) plane exhibited possible polarization hysteresis, which is a well-known characteristic of ferroelectric materials with a P r (remnant polarization) = 1.8 μC/cm2 and almost comparable to peptide-induced BaTiO3. Such a large P r with smaller coercive electric field (~2.5 kV) is unprecedented in MOF and may be due to the presence of anion perchlorate in this channel, like a typical H-bonded ferroelectric TGS (triglycine sulfate). This respect was confirmed by its large dielectric constant.

elements.content: Polarization versus applied electric field at 0.5 kHz for 1. The blue line was added later for describing the upper- and lower-closing mouth routine hysteresis loop and is not an experimental result.
elements.clean_text: 4  Polarization versus applied electric field at 0.5 kHz for 1. The blue line was added later for describing the upper- and lower-closing mouth routine hysteresis loop and is not an experimental result.

elements.content: Figure a shows that at low frequency and 250 K, DL tan δ [= ε2(T)/ε1(T)] gives a low value of ca. 0.4. Thus, by combining with the real part of permittivity [ε(T) = ε1(T) + iε2(T)], the DC magnitude at low temperature resembles that of organic polymers found in the copolymer of poly(vinylidene fluoride) and trifluoroethylene. No relaxation process was observed and the permittivity maximum value (both the real and imaginary parts) was found to remain unchanged which, to our knowledge, is a rare phenomenon. In contrast, at 360 K, DL tan δ displays a high value close to 100 that remains unchanged at two low frequencies (100−1000 Hz), as depicted in Figure b. This abnormal behavior is not known for either pure inorganic or organic compounds and suggests there could be conducting dielectric species (its conductivity with ca. 7 × 10−7 S cm−1 such as HClO4) in 1, which is shown to be present by X-ray analysis. In addition, this behavior resembles that found in food and water containing compounds where the large water content was reasoned to be responsible for the high DL [quality factor Q (defined as 1/DL tangent) of ca. 1−10; in our work Q ≈ 0.01]. Although a high DL is undesirable for dielectric materials employed in capacitors, the materials utilized for dielectric heating (electrocaloric effect as a cause of dielectric loss) is essential. Its large dielectric loss feature is in good agreement with its ferroelectric hysteresis loop where its hysteresis loop displays a lower closing mouth route because most small dielectric loss ferroelectrics normally display an upper closing mouth route (the blue line). Thus, its unique DL property would imply that 1 may have useful applications in self-induction-heating techniques.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows that at low frequency and 250 K, DL tan δ [= ε2(T)/ε1(T)] gives a low value of ca. 0.4. Thus, by combining with the real part of permittivity [ε(T) = ε1(T) + iε2(T)], the DC magnitude at low temperature resembles that of organic polymers found in the copolymer of poly(vinylidene fluoride) and trifluoroethylene. No relaxation process was observed and the permittivity maximum value (both the real and imaginary parts) was found to remain unchanged which, to our knowledge, is a rare phenomenon. In contrast, at 360 K, DL tan δ displays a high value close to 100 that remains unchanged at two low frequencies (100-1000 Hz), as depicted in Figure b. This abnormal behavior is not known for either pure inorganic or organic compounds and suggests there could be conducting dielectric species (its conductivity with ca. 7 × 10-7 S cm-1 such as HClO4) in 1, which is shown to be present by X-ray analysis. In addition, this behavior resembles that found in food and water containing compounds where the large water content was reasoned to be responsible for the high DL [quality factor Q (defined as 1/DL tangent) of ca. 1-10; in our work Q ~ 0.01]. Although a high DL is undesirable for dielectric materials employed in capacitors, the materials utilized for dielectric heating (electrocaloric effect as a cause of dielectric loss) is essential. Its large dielectric loss feature is in good agreement with its ferroelectric hysteresis loop where its hysteresis loop displays a lower closing mouth route because most small dielectric loss ferroelectrics normally display an upper closing mouth route (the blue line). Thus, its unique DL property would imply that 1 may have useful applications in self-induction-heating techniques.

elements.content:
The present work on in situ trapping acidic species provides a new impetus to examine the physical properties of novel MOFs.

Detailed experimental procedures, IR spectroscopic data, additional ORTEP views, and X-ray crystallographic cif files. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Detailed experimental procedures, IR spectroscopic data, additional ORTEP views, and X-ray crystallographic cif files. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data of MOF 1, C26H27ClN10O8Zn2, M r = 773.77, tetragonal, P4, a = b = 15.9394(4) Å, c = 6.0101(3) Å, α = β = γ = 90°, V = 1526.95(9) Å3, Z = 2, D c = 1.683 Mg m−3, R 1 = 0.0375, wR 2 = 0.0827, μ = 1.725 mm−1, S = 0.749; Flack = 0.032(19)

cln_elements.content:
Hydrothermal reaction of (L)-N-(2-cyano-benzyl)-(S)-proline with NaN3, Zn(ClO4)2, and H2O gave {[Zn(TBPR)⊂0.25(HClO4)](0.25HClO4)} n 1; TBPR = (S)-N-2-tetrazoylbenzylproline), a unique homochiral one-dimensional cage- or tanklike metal−organic framework (MOF). Permittivity and ferroelectric property measurements reveal that 1 not only exhibits a high dielectric loss but also displays a possible hysteresis loop with a large remnant polarization (P r = 1.8 μC/cm2) and a lower closing mouth route.

References

metadata.title:
Tanklike Metal−Organic Framework Filled with Perchloric Acid and Its Dielectric−Ferroelectric Properties
Communications
